title: 115_hr5967
content:
The "Export Promotion Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The findings section highlights key points related to export promotion. The Export Promotion Act acknowledges the importance of exports to the US economy, with 11.6 million jobs supported by exports. Despite export growth since 2010, goals set by the Administration have not been met. Federal assistance is crucial for small and mid-size businesses to access new markets. Numerous resources are available at Federal agencies for companies looking to export. Federal agencies such as the Department of Agriculture, Small Business Administration, and Export-Import Bank offer programs for technical assistance, financing, and market development for US companies. However, there is significant overlap among agencies, leading to confusion, inefficiency, and difficulty in tracking the success of export promotion efforts. The U.S. Government Accountability Office found shortcomings in Federal export assistance programs, including lack of collaboration, communication, and coordination among agencies. Significant changes are needed to maintain global economic competitiveness for small businesses. By consolidating functions of multiple Federal agencies into the new Export Promotion Agency in the Department of Commerce, small- and mid-size businesses can utilize a one-stop-shop for export assistance, reducing waste, improving access to information, and cutting bureaucracy. The new Export Promotion Agency in the Department of Commerce aims to streamline export assistance for small- and mid-size businesses by cutting bureaucracy and improving coordination with other agencies like the Trade and Development Agency and the Bureau of Economic and Business Affairs. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Agency" refers to the Export Promotion Agency established under section 4(a). "Functions" include authorities, powers, programs, projects, duties, and responsibilities. "Personnel" refers to officers and employees. "Under Secretary" means the Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Promotion appointed under section 4(b). The Export Promotion Agency is established in the Department of Commerce, with the Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Promotion appointed by the President. Functions of various agencies are transferred to the new Agency. The Bureau of Economic and Business Affairs of the Department of State is amended to include the Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Promotion. Section 5314 of title 5, United States Code, is also amended to include the Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Promotion. The Bureau of Economic and Business Affairs of the Department of State is amended to include the Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Promotion. Section 5314 of title 5, United States Code, is also amended to include the Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Promotion. Additionally, there is a focus on organizational structure and performance metrics. The Under Secretary will develop an organizational structure for the Agency to consolidate programs and create metrics to measure performance in exports, business concerns, and presence in foreign markets. A report must be submitted within 12 months of the Under Secretary taking office. The Under Secretary will submit a report to Congress containing required matters within 12 months of taking office. The Under Secretary must provide an annual report to Congress on the Agency's operations, including the effectiveness of its organizational structure and data received from applying metrics. During the transition period, the President can designate acting officials to fill vacant positions until Senate confirmation, with compensation based on the rates of the respective offices they act in or the offices they held at the time of designation. During the transition period, the President can designate acting officials to fill vacant positions until Senate confirmation, with compensation based on the rates of the respective offices they act in or the offices they held at the time of designation. This Act does not require Senate approval for the appointment of officers whose functions are transferred to the Agency under section 4(c) and whose duties remain consistent before and after the transfer. Personnel, assets, and obligations of transferred functions shall be allocated by the Under Secretary with approval from the Director. During the transition period, the President can designate acting officials to fill vacant positions until Senate confirmation, with compensation based on the rates of the respective offices they act in or the offices they held at the time of designation. This Act does not require Senate approval for the appointment of officers whose functions are transferred to the Agency under section 4(c) and whose duties remain consistent before and after the transfer. Personnel, assets, and obligations of transferred functions shall be allocated by the Under Secretary with approval from the Director. The Under Secretary shall have all functions relating to the entity or program that any other official could by law exercise in relation to the entity or program immediately before such transfer, and shall have in addition all functions vested in the Under Secretary by this Act or other law. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, at such time or times as the Director shall provide, is authorized to make incidental transfers. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is authorized to make determinations and dispositions necessary for the transfer of functions, entities, or programs as required by the Act. This includes terminating affairs of entities and programs that are terminated by the Act. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is authorized to transfer positions within the Senior Executive Service in connection with functions, entities, or programs as required by the Act. Savings provisions are in place for completed administrative actions. Savings provisions ensure that completed administrative actions of an entity or program remain unaffected by the Act or transfer to the Agency, continuing until legally amended or terminated. Pending civil actions shall continue unaffected by the enactment of the Act or transfer to the Agency, with proceedings, appeals, judgments, and enforcement proceeding as usual. The provisions of the Act do not impact ongoing proceedings, including applications for licenses, permits, certificates, or financial assistance. Pending civil actions will continue unaffected by the Act, including proceedings for licenses, permits, certificates, or financial assistance. Proceedings related to transferred functions will be continued, with orders remaining in effect until modified or revoked by the relevant Federal agency or court. On the effective date of this Act, certain entities and programs will terminate, including the International Trade Administration, the Office of International Trade of the Small Business Administration, the Trade Development Agency, and the Export Credit Guarantee Program. The Under Secretary is authorized to issue regulations for the transfer of proceedings under this Act. On the effective date of this Act, certain entities and programs will terminate, including the Export Credit Guarantee Program and the Facilities Guarantee Program of the Department of Agriculture, and the Bureau of Economic and Business Affairs of the Department of State. SEC. 8. REFERENCES.

Any function transferred to the Agency under section 4(c) will be exercised by the Under Secretary. References to the head of the entity or program will now refer to the Under Secretary of Commerce for Export Promotion or the Export Promotion Agency.

SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The Act will take effect one year after its enactment.
